This thread looks like mutating into another polemic of science versus religion. But before it does that, perhaps an excursion into the "philosophy" of science might be diverting.
 
 That science can answer (at least in principle) all questions concerning the natural world is virtually an axiom. I say "virtually" because there is some doubt about it. 
 
 For instance: science proceeds on the basis of empiricism - which implies that every claim to knowledge must be put to the test of experience, and if found deficient, rejected. Thus all the conclusions of authority, revelation, tradition, etc. are put in doubt. But what is meant by the "test of experience" ? There is room for sceptical inquiry here. 
 
 Another instance: the scientist uses inductive reasoning to arrive at a conclusion - which means passing from the observed to the unobserved in order to formulate a prediction or a "general law". But a general law covers indefinitely many examples, so how can we be certain that the evidence on which the general law is formulated will always remain adequate ? Can we be confident of the validity of inductive reasoning ?
 
 I'm attracted by the "clinical" nature of science and I'm weary of the endless and messy equivocations of religion etc. But once the detritus of superstition has been cleared out of the way, is science the only route to knowledge and truth about the natural world ?
